And the pepper was that fine-grained stuff one might find in a shaker in the Midwest.  I will defintely NOT go back, nor inflict the "dining" experience on anyone else.

Oh, and the music selection felt wonky: from loud and uber-edgy to something one could carry on a conversation over.

Sorry, Soluna owners, your restaurant sucks.  95% because of the food.  (Your servers really do try to do a god job.)  Oh, and you're way overpriced.  The Sf Public library serves WAY better food for way less $.
author: Karen S.

description:
I came in for drinks- the service at the bar was good. Even though they did not have the liquor to create my drink of choice that night, they were still able to serve me something good. 

The prices were a bit high for some things but over all the place is clean and the temperament of the people working there is friendly. 

I am giving this place 3 stars for the simple fact that it is like any ordinary bar- it was good but not great- nothing really caught my eye and I would have forgotten the name of this place if it hadn't been for me taking a business card. The best way to improve on the business, is to cheapen up a bit and having more if not better specials. 
Again until some little tweaks need to be made so that "average" becomes "superb"
author: Alan O.

description: My friends and I were very excited to try this restaurant, as it was somewhere we had never been to before and it seemed like a classy and neat place from other online reviews we had read.  However, our experience was less than mediocre.  We got there five minutes before our reservation and it not only took the host twenty minutes to get our table ready, but he was also very rude to all of us as well. It was nighttime and he did not ask to take our coats, or to take a seat at the bar - as he did kindly with all of the other customers that came in after us.  Our actual dining experience was not commendable either.  Overall this place has HORRIBLE customer service.  Their workers are RUDE and do not make you feel welcomed AT ALL.  Needless to say myself and my friends will not be coming back here or recommending it to ANYONE we know.
author: Melanie S.

description:
My gal pals and I had dinner here prior to seeing Wicked at the Orpheum.  The service was pretty good, though there was some confusion as to where the hostess intended on seating us.  This minor kerfuffle was erased from our memory by copious amounts of red wine, Frenet and Prosecco.

I had the Dungeness Crab bisque as an appetizer and it was delish!  My friend Holly and I split a NY strip for dinner and I have to say that I was rather uncomfortably full at the end of the meal.  That's a good thing.  Plus they had broccoli with bacon and sauteed onions - I'm going to have to figure out how to make that stuff - it was really really good!

Both of my friends had the seared sea scallops - they were tasty - but, not out of the ordinary.  Then again, I've never met a scallop I didn't like.

Overall we all really enjoyed our meal and the company we were with.  I'd not hesitate to go back to Soluna for dinner before the theater the next time we have tickets to something in that area.

Yum, yum, yum!
author: Kate R.

description:
there doesn't seem to be too many choices to have a nice dinner around the Orpheum Theatre, so despite that I read not so good reviews I decided to give it a chance.

Unfortunately, they just proved that those bad reviews do have a lot of ground, the service was just bad. We went there on a Wednesday and although the place didn't seem busy and that we told the waiter we had tickets for the show, everything took forever. By the time that we got the drinks we had decided that at this pace we should rather skip any appetizer and dessert.

Food was good, but got the feeling that the chicken breast that I ordered had been sitting under the lamp for a while before it made it to the table.

if the price range had been cheaper, then I will give them more stars.
author: Joako F.

description:
Employees were pleasant.

Very short not-scary walking distance to Orpheum  & BART/MUNI. 

The service was very slow and quite poor.   

I left feeling really disappointed.

I won't be back.
author: Megan G.

description: Our experience here was wonderful. We had Friday at 6pm reservations. Found free parking right in front (free after 6pm). There was no hostess at the front but we were noticed and seated right away. Bar was busy but we were the only people dinning in the back. Cocktails were strong and food was fresh and delicious. It was nice to eat somewhere on a Friday night in the city and feel like you were the only people there. I can't say how great the food was either. 5 stars and we will be back.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I planned a Valentines day weekend for my boyfriend this year (instead of vice versa) and stayed about 2 miles up from Soluna at the Omni Hotel on California. I had reservations for about 5 other places till finally deciding on Soluna to eat at, for several different reasons.
1.The prefix wasn't OUTRAGEOUSLY overpriced by any means compared to several other places i inquired with.(36$ compared to a 75$ per person)

2.The atmosphere was said to be romantic and a cozier feeling, which meant to me that it wasnt so big that it felt cold, and the ambiance shown from the pictures looked dim lit and very romantic to me at least.

3.Lastly I was searching for a place that would have great atmosphere and amazing food but didnt want something  too elite that my boyfriend was forced to wear a jacket. Soluna was described as casual elegant, therefore i could dress up without looking overdressed, and he could do the same..(aka he wore his vans with dress pants...so sexy haha)

Upon arriving, we were asked to wait at the bar for a few minutes, although we had a reservation for 7:45, but didnt bother us at all. The atmosphere was very romantic, lighting was dim, it was NOT LOUD at all, but more of a murmur of whispers, which was a little sexy to me. The music played also added to the ambience which was a lounge type, zero 7ish style.

 We were seated quickly after being placed at the bar to a table that was slightly close to the others, but wasn't invasive.We actually had several different waitresses from the time we were seated till the end, which was kidnof expected due to the 'holiday'. 

From the Prefixe menu, my boyfriend ordered the mac n cheese for the first course, and the New York Strip for the main entree. I ordered the caesar salad and the crab stuffed ravioli. We also ordered the bread and olive oil 'on request'. 

My caesar salad was ABSOLUTELY delicous, very crisp, sort of iceberg style, where you cut your own bite sized pieces. Jareds mac n cheese, was an explosion of delicious cheese's combined, which came in a small plate, but was very filling. The bread came out a little late, but didnt bother us much.

My main course was probably one of the best meals I had in a while. 4 large raviolis stuffed with crab in this creamy seafood sauce, which I WISH i knew what was in it, because it was absolutely delicious. Jared's steak was good, but was infatuated with the vegetables served in this soy sauce, and the potatoes, which were like a fried potato puff, with creamy mash potatoes in the middle, There was also a wasabi like collored drizzle served with them. All tasted delicious and complimented eachother beautifully.

Lastly even though we were stuffed, we had our eyes on peoples desserts the second we walked in, and wanted the chocolate cake with chocolate covered strawberries on top. However, they ran out right before us so instead got the chocolate covered strawberries, alone. We didnt realize we both got a dessert, so we had 6 huge chocolate covered strawberries to share. Needless to say we left absolutely STUFFED!!


We asked the waitress, who served us for the majority of the end of our meal (whom was an absolute doll) if we should call a cab, or hail one,  and they said they would call one for us. 

We were walking out to leave when the owner, Ed Ivey came up to us on the phone saying he was trying to get us a cab, but it may be a few minutes due to the night. With no answer on the other end, Ed hung up the phone asked us where we were staying, and said if you don't mind riding in his car he would love to take us AND DROVE US BACK TO OUR HOTEL!!!!!!! saved us 10 bucks and TALK ABOUT CUSTOMER SERVICE!! It was an already absolutely enjoyable meal, and that was the icing on our already eaten dessert, (cake).

If your in the mood for a romantic, delicious and gourmet meal & dessert with exceptional customer service, eat at Soluna you wont regret it! :)

and if your reading:
 THANKS ED AGAIN, YOUR HOSPITALITY BLEW US OUT OF THE WATER, AND YOUR RESTAURANT HAD US COMING BACK FOR MORE, WE"LL SEE YOU SOON FOR LUNCH!!
:)
author: Kai N.

description: I'm a friggin happy camper. I've come twice and both times it's exactly what I want. The bar is elegant and lovely. The owner is serving specialty cocktails of his own creation. The food is fancy and hip and if I want to have Mac and cheese with a side of roasted duck breast, I can. This restaurant is clearly the manifested passion of someone who has a passion for the dinning experience. Its an oasis in the ghetto and well worth the trip from across town. It buddies up against the tenderloin public garden so the view is that of a farmers paddock. I get the cheese plate (served with homemade black pepper strawberry jam and candied almonds for 11 bucks, pretty good deal) and a specialty cocktail (made with lusty love) on my way home from work and it makes me feel like I'm actually living my life. The place is bustling but not crowded. You can always grab a seat at the bar or sit down for dinner. You should come down and friendly up with the bar tenders before it's the next hot spot in SF.
author: Eden M.

description:
Came here for the first time last week after an event at city hall. it was close-by and had nice ambiance, so that was already a plus for me.

Got a mojito first, which is my favorite drink and tasted pretty good. My friend and I ordered a salad (forgot the name) but it was very interesting. Had huge lettuce leaves and some bacon crisps on it. Seemed pretty light and tasted good. Also got the oysters which were very fresh and tasty, and ended with the mac n cheese, which was very hot and cheesy, but didn't taste too rich. All three dishes were appetizers, but we weren't too hungry and wanted to try a bit of everything, so they were definitely good choices. 

Finally we had dessert and picked the chocolate pretzels. I never heard of them before, so wanted to give them a try. They were definitely interesting. I expected them to be shaped like a pretzel, but it was just a little bun with chocolate inside. It was very warm, and came with extra chocolate sauce and also their special honey peanut butter sauce, which i LOVED. Definitely rich, but the portion is small and when u share it with a friend, it's the perfect amount after a nice meal! =)
author: Louisa L.

description:
A conversation I heard tonight at Soluna;

"Well then young lady, do you mind telling me where you've been spending the evening?"

"Daddy, it's all right."

"Oh yes, everything's fine, I always stop by the police station in the middle of the night to pick up my daughter. Don't you realize that by morning this will be all over town?"

"Well we were just trying to warn people" 

"After all I am the principal at the high school. Young man this is the last time you'll going to take my daughter out!" 

"Steve didn't do anything wrong!"

I thought I was having flashbacks, and then I realized that my dad is not a principal, and I never would have been spending the evening with this shady Steve character, and that, should this have been a real life scenario taken from the memoirs of my youth, my reputation ready to be tainted by vicious rumors spread about town, I would not have been laughing nearly as hard as I was this evening.

What??? 

I have no flipping idea how I have missed this place for so long. What is this I speak of? Why, its Monday double feature night at Soluna! 

Apparently there is always a theme, this evenings pieced together with All About Eve (filmed at the Curran Theater where Jersey Boys is playing) and The Blob (as seen in Jersey Boys) as we, apparently, watched with the cast of Jersey Boys. 

I think we were all too distracted by the movies, munchies, plush booths and cheap drinks ($3 drafts, $4 well drinks, $5 wine) to even realize we were in the presence of celebrities. We did, however, find a place that may just become a Monday night tradition.
author: Drue C.

description:
Had reservations at Soluna Cafe on a Wednesday night.   Food was good.

Not sure why we had to wait almost 35 minutes before ANY employee wait staff even stopped by just to say  "WELCOME"... or "CAN I BRING YOU ANYTHING".

The restaurant was NOT crowded.   The UNTRAINED waitress didn't even ask if we wanted anything to DRINK  or if we wanted an appetizer to start with.

After finally getting someone's attention that we were READY TO ORDER,  we had to wait maybe 35 more minutes before any food showed up.  

Kind of embarrassing for a well established restaurant to have really inept, untrained wait staff!
author: Russ B.

description:
A great place for lunch when you find yourself in the Civic Center area.  Trendy, colorful, tasty.  Reasonable prices. 

The staff is friendly, but varied in their experience.  Some seem quite savvy, others seem to be stretched.  

I booked through Open Table.  Easy.  

There's often street parking nearby, but there are also lots around the corner, or of course, the underground lot underneath the square.
author: Bevy M.

description: We had an excellent experience at Soluna Cafe. We were held up in traffic and only had half an hour to grab a bite before our granddaughter's ballet recital. We thought we might be able to order something from the bar. The server couldn't have been nicer!  She seated us in the restaurant and assured us that if we ordered a salad she could have it out immediately. We had a delicious spinach salad and cheese plate and were on our way in 20 minutes. I know others have commented about slow service, but we had the opposite experience.
author: Susan G.

description:
Had the apocalypse come after dinner on 6/6/06 I'd have died a happy man.

The lovely and I had a gift certificate for $70. Being teachers, we usually share an appetizer and/or dessert, but not tonight. In the very best way possible, we should have. The portions are very generous.

A great sign: While handing back the menu, my eye caught some print about $31.xx prix fixe and our server was fulfilling her duty before I could inquire about it. She returned to our table to inform us that there would be a surcharge of $5 for the caviar selection on the prix fixe dinner, and assumed we'd like to pay less and get dessert at no extra charge. We love her.

Everything we ate had a great counter play to it. I started with a warm goat cheese salad w/ fresh beets while cutie had caviar 'shooters' on little roast half potatoes w/creme fresh. Both were delicious and suitable for a light dinner.

My New York strip was fork-tender with a nice bourdelaise, asparagus and blue cheese mashed potatoes so rich I might have reversed its name. The juicy pork loin was nicely complimented by spinach and an OMG-give-me-a-bowl-of-this-to-take-home sweet potato hash with applewood-smoked bacon.

Lovely had a nice throat-warming collapsed chocolate souffle. I had the best strawberry shortcake, ever. Fresh strawberries and vanilla gelato between a sliced lemon-poppyseed biscuit with fresh whipped cream on top. It was big enough for 2-3 people and I ate the whole...damn...thing. 

Our tab was $2.54 + an 800% tip. We staggered back to the car and watched for roiling dark clouds overhead with huge smiles on our faces.
author: Andy R.

description: Would be 5 if the coffee was hot!  Best fried chicken in San Fran and a fabulously strong and tasty mimosa.  Happy Mother's Day to me!
author: oyefunke a.

description: My youngest daughter is in Law school down the street and this our new fav spot! Food was excellent and drinks were awesome, especially the cherry bomb drink. Mya was an awesome waitress too!
author: N T.

description: The food here was really good I had a civic burger and hot coopa mea. It is more on the Pricey side but it is worth it.
author: Robles E.

description:
For Christmas, I am sending the people who own this place a huge shaker full of SALT.  And maybe a gigantic grinder of black PEPPER.  With instructions.  Maybe even a video.

The food here is WOEFULLY under seasoned, and in some cases the flavor combinations are ill conceived.   

For example, I tried the lamb shanks last night, which were served with baby vegetables and an orange gremolata over blue cheese mashed potatoes.  With all the ingredients in the gremolata, the only thing I could taste was ORANGE--overpowerlingly so, and there was absolutely no hint of the blue cheese in the potatoes.  

The lamb at least tasted a bit like lamb, but the whole thing suffered from a lack of salt and pepper in preparation.  If you don't season as you go with dishes that have as many ingredients and layers of flavor as this one, there is no way you can add enough salt and pepper later to salvage the dish.  Sadly, the lamb shanks themselves were rather unappetizingly prepared, with a lot of the stringy, greyish connective tissue still attached.

The result was a plate full of food with literally dozens of ingredients, each one of which should bring some flavor to the party, but what I ended up with was a mess of a plate with no flavor at all.

It was just as bad last night on IQ's side of the table.  His fried chicken breast was crispy and the breading was not burnt, but again, the dish completely lacked flavor, both in the chicken's flesh and in the otherwise decently textured breading.  The mashed potatoes under this plank of chicken were similarly underseasoned, and the watermelon relish on the side was bland, watery, and unappetizing.

The only item on our table last night that was an unqualified success was the delicately seasoned, flaky and tender biscuit.  Of course, a biscuit is born to hold butter, and nary a pat was found on our table.

Service is indifferent here, too.  We had an hour to finish our meal before the opera, something we made clear to the restaurant when we made our reservations and again when we arrived, but there was a bit too much time before we could order, and once the food arrived, the checkback came late.  I needed a steak knife for my meat, and when you have to wait for someone to troll by to get one, it's an extra aggravation.

We go to the opera or the symphony with a reasonable amount of frequency and it would be great if this was a reliable choice for a good supper before hand--especially when you're larding up for a 3 1/2 hour marathan like last night's performance of Idomeneo at the opera---but sadly I don't think Soluna fits the bill for us.
author: Kevin S.

description: First time here and really enjoyed all our entries (antipasti platter with goat gouda and saucisson sec, steamed clams , nicoise salad and pork chop).  Manager comped us a cantaloupe sorbet and chatted for a few minutes which was great.  We also loved our server, there wasn't a single thing she could have done better.  This is a great venue pre- symphony and we will definitely  be back!
author: Jeanne C.

description:
YUMMMM-4-DAYS!

My LAUUURD hunnnie.... the fud was deee-lish!  The COCKtails were sinful and the service was better than any gloryhole I've been to in this "no-earthly-good" city... YUMMMM-Fo'-DAYS!
author: Lando T.

description:
I been here few times and had great time all the time.
Food is tasty and service is good as well.
They change to dance floors after 10pm. 
I used to like Tuesday night! Great music.
author: Megumi T.

description:
The first thing that must be said about Soluna is that the ambience is lovely and loungy. Can I say loungy? Would that be th correct spelling if it were even a word? Is that off-topic? Anyway, it's exactly the type of bar/restaurant that strikes my fancy.

I've never actually eaten dinner here, but I've had lunch a few times,  happy hour a few more times, and evening cocktails once. Tasty lunch menu, including a lovely nicoise salad and some great fancy comfort foods like mac and cheese and grilled ham and cheese with tomato soup. A little more than I would typically spend on lunch, but a nice escape for one of those the-office-is-evil days.

Happy hour is great too, with $4 well drinks, $5 glasses of wine and beers... well, I don't drink beer but I think they are 3 or 4 bucks. They also have some tasty specialty cocktails. They also have a nice bar food menu, including the aforementioned cheese filled items.

Stopped in for happy hour yesterday and they showed Oh Brother Where Art Thou? One of my favorite flicks, in a cozy setting, with wine and cheese, good company... it's tough to argue with that.

The only reason to withold a fifth star is that although the food is completely enjoyable, there's nothing exceptional about it. But it's tasty, reasonably priced, and a fun place to hang out, so at 4 starss, it's still highly recommended.
author: Mandy B.

description:
My mom and I had dinner here before a show at the Orpheum.  A nice cozy spot, okay food, okay service, okay drinks. 
I don't think I'd treat it as a destination, but as a spot for dinner when you're in the area, it's a good pick.
I had a tasty salad and short ribs that were more fat than meat.
The chicken dish was good, the mashed potatoes delicious, but the salsa clashed and we scraped most of it off.
We had these little pretzel bite things for dessert - stuffed with chocolate and served with a peanut butter sauce and a caramel sauce; nom.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
My girlfriend and I went here yesterday because it was closed to the Orpheum Theater (we went to see Billy Elliott). I made a reservation for 6:30 pm and we were seated immediately. Yes, I agreed that it was darker toward the back of the restaurant.

After reading reviews about the slow services before a show, we told our waitress that we have a show at 8 pm and asked her to give us the check with the entrees which she did. We order the dessert together with the entree orders. Our waitress gave us great prompt services.

I ordered the Pork Tenderloin medium cooked and it came out delicious, moist and tender. The two side vegetables (zucchini & potatoes) that came with the meal were also excellent.

My friend had the Civic Burger - really, really tasty.  The bun so was so light, the meat was juicy and the picked red onions added just enough saltiness.  However, she said the fries were so-so.

Some tips, you need to ask the waitress for bread which we did and the bread came promptly. If you show your waitress your show tickets, the restaurant will comp you one free dessert.  Comping the dessert itself is worth 2 stars as described below.

For dessert, we ask the waitress what she recommends and she said the White Chocolate Bread Pudding is outstanding. The bread pudding portion was large enough for two people to share. The bread pudding was accompanied by a scoop of homemade vanilla bourbon ice cream - creamy, not too sweet, and the bourbon was not strong at all.  The bread pudding itself was awesome.  I loved the contrast in textures but especially loved the toasty, crunchy parts of the bread pudding.

We got out of the restaurant with15 minutes to spare before the show. Our experience with Soluna was very good.
author: Mary g.

description:
There's a lot good about Soluna.  1/2 drinks from 3 to 6, and all night Monday.  Movie night on Mondays.  A very nice lunch menu, and good stuff on the dinner menu (I've done more the hors d'oeuvres route).  Jack the bartender?   Great.  I like the manager and the owner, and I've found the wait staff to be friendly.   

Do you sense a but?  But  . . .  .  But . . . .  Generally, we (my office) tried to be promoters (have office lunches there, parties, drinks), and yet there have been some issues.  

One, no half price drinks at the tables?  We were regulars, and I raced in to have my one drink half price (before starting to pay full) and talked about it audibly in front of our server, and I was charged full price (as were my friends).  The restaurant was empty.  They said it was okay to sit at the table, and not word one about the "no half price" even though we were regulars. That was not cool.   

Two, I had a party there:  talked about it in advance with the owner, thought I had it all worked out.  Went a day or two before to work out the menu details, and somehow, it hadn't gotten on the calendar (apparently, it was not communicated to the manager).  No big deal, these things happen, but they were all quite snippy about it .  I understand that they were stressed, but it was not my fault, and life is too short not to try to take stuff in stride.   Then, when we arrived for the party?  No party for us in sight.   Hastings students everywhere.  Fine, but they could have moved them up front.   Or told me.  There was a very uncomfortable feeling that it was our fault.  Not cool.  Waited a good half hour b/f everything settled in, and then it was fine.

I still like the concept, but I will say that we have moved elsewhere most nights for drinks.   We used to go only to Soluna, and now we crawl the Tenderloin.  Which has been good for expanding my horizons and my enthusiasm for the TL, which has a lot to offer.  I still go to Soluna for the occasional lunch and the occasional drink, but my enthusiasm (our enthusiasm) (meaning my office's) is dashed.  In fairness, I think the people are nice, but it really wasn't a good feeling.   There were a few other more subtle dis experiences like this, too.  So the bloom's off the Soluna.  As my friend (the honoree of the party, actually) says, dis me once, shame on you.  Dis me twice?  Shame on me.
author: Laurel B.

description:
I went crazy trying to find a good, affordable restaurant within walking distance from the opera.  

Crab/Sole dish:
I had the dungeness crab stuffed inside a sole with the lemon/butter  hollandaise sauce.  Not that great.  Not much flavor and the creamy sauce overtakes the seafood.  

Ambiance:
Nice- interesting art on the walls, dimly lit, stylized lamps.

Service:
Great.  Our server was attentive and was totally understanding to the fact we had to jet out for the opera.  

All in all the food wasn't worth the price ($24/25 for the sole) but I don't have heart to give this place only 2 stars since the service was good and decor not bad. 

And it is indeed walking distance to the opera.  So convenience is a plus.
author: Alias A.

description:
After the Sunday Farmer's Market, my husband and I walked by here, when we noticed we were more hungry than we thought. I did not expect what awaited me...
First of all, the place is quite big and I  personally think it's missing some flair but the service is friendly and attentive.
But then I ordered the grass-fed burger with truffle fries and my Sunday was perfect. I am a sucker for grass-fed beef and did not expect it here. Positive surprises are best!!
author: Alexandra D.

description:
With so few options near the Orpheum, it was fine for appetizers, drinks, and dessert before Wicked, but we probably wouldn't go back otherwise. Even at happy hour, the food was pretty pricey.

The positive is, if you bring in your Wicked tix, they give your party one free dessert.
author: Jen Y.

description:
I came here for a fast lunch after a city hall wedding. It happened to be Valentines Day and I happened to received a red rose lapel corsage for the ceremony. I was presiding over it, not getting married. The ceremony, not the corsage.

The meal was lovely, I had the nicoise salad, and the hubby had some sort of a chicken sandwich with a TON of avocado on it. Both were very tasty.

However, it was a little awkward when our server kept giving me sympathetic looks. I'm fairly certain that she figured I had the worst husband in the world, who had purchased for me a red rose lapel corsage for Valentines Day. I know how it looked, but I SWEAR it was from the ceremony...
author: Dixon T.

description:
I've been to Soluna twice -- once was a few years ago on a random tuesday when it wasn't busy, the other was recently on a very busy evening. 

On this very busy evening, we were seated at the bar (we thought we'd get our food faster this way) and ordered drinks and our meal (apps and entrees).  After about 30 minutes or so of waiting for any sign that our fries would arrive and seeing people served who came in after us, we asked about the status of our order.  Lisa, the server/bartender, informed us everyone was trying to get their food in time for their respective shows and that the kitchen was still working on it.  Not exactly very warm or apologetic.

In any case, after waiting another 15 minutes for any sign of our order, we cancelled it so we could grab a bite in time for our show at the Orpheum.  Lisa was very nonchalant, not apologetic or really gave any clue that she cared we were leaving -- at least pretend a little bit so that we would come back again!  The group next to us left as well and same blank expression/response.

In any case, I would not recommend Soluna, particularly on a night where there are things going on -- Soluna just can't handle it.  Go to the mexican place down the street instead -- great burritos!
author: Mitzi C.

description:
I really want to love Soluna, but it seems like every time we go there they are out of something I want or they're understaffed. They serve good California cuisine, have a creative cocktail menu and well-stocked bar. The decor is warm and inviting, and they play good music.

We recently ate there on a Thursday night; my husband ordered a martini, and neither the bar nor kitchen could come up with either an olive or a lemon for a twist. It just seemed like they weren't prepared to be open for business. It wasn't a HUGE deal, but something like that has happened every time we've eaten there.
author: rachel m.

description:
This was our spot after the Raggamuffin festival last weekend.  Upon entering the place we had to wait for a table but the whole joint was open.  It didnt make sense to me.  We got sat in the very back .....which made me question whether I actually looked THAT drunk. I ask the waiter for a beer and a Belgian beer to be exact and he tells me they don't have any.  Then I ask him what they have....."FAT TIRE"  I then wondered if anyone was home upstairs.  I order the belgian beer and tell him what's up.  I don't think he liked me.  The food was ok.  I did have these awesome Gouda potatoes but I can't remember what else I had.  HAHA.  

Karlee had these brussel sprouts that she loved. My man ordered the scallops but there were only 3 to be found on his plate.  

I'd say it's a "hit or miss" kind of joint.
author: Shelly S.

description:
i am so unhappy with soluna that i created this yelp account.

here's the story: i flew all the way from DC to surprise my mom for mother's day, and being the good children we are, decided to take mom to a nice brunch. my brother made the reservations and specifically chose Soluna because they advertised a mother's day brunch menu with "bottomless mimosas" on their website. 

but the brunch menu was non-existent! and the mimosas had bottoms! Apparently they forgot to update the website. UGH. we would have left, but there's not much else within walking distance. so we resolved to eat sandwiches at 11am. 

had the service been okay i would have given them 3 stars. but as it was, the server was unpleasant, and even though there were only 3 other tables in the restaurant, i had to remind her a few times about my mom's coffee. 

we still had a good time together as a family, but i was very irked - and anyone who knows me knows im not easily irked! i felt they were extremely unprofessional. my mom deserved better!
author: ali k.

description:
My husband and I went here before going to see West-Side Story at the Orpheum.  It's kind of in a funny location next to Hastings Law School, but it's really convenient to the theater.  We had reservations but they put as at a small little table that was almost underneath the waiter's station (with the pitchers of water, baskets of bread, etc.)  We're not picky people so it was fine but it was a bit odd to be almost underneath a ledge filled with dripping pitchers of water.  
The ambience in the restaurant is really nice, I like the colors and lighting.  The wait staff was very friendly and checked in on us just enough, recognizing that we were on a date (one of my biggest pet peeves is hovering wait staff).  The timeliness of our food was also perfect (I also dislike when courses come too fast, the time between our app and entrees were perfect).  
We split the stuffed calamari for an appetizer...wow.  It was so creative with the butternut squash filling, perfect for an October evening.  I also really appreciated that it was just two (large) pieces of calamari.  Quality over quantity here.  I had the seared ahi tuna and my husband had the halibut.  Both dishes were perfectly executed with really creative touches (like the husbands mini green been casserole - just like Thanksgiving!).    
A lot of the comments here have been negative about their portion sizes...I thought they were perfect.  Americans have become too used to huge portion sizes.  We got just the right amount of food and the price was reasonable.  The ingredients were fresh and used very creatively.  
My only complaints are the seating I mentioned before AND that when we came back after the show to see if we could get dessert and a drink and the bartender was very rude to us.  He seemed to just have his regulars hanging out and didn't want us to be there - so we left!
author: Kasey H.

description: We were a party of three and having seen Soluna Cafe pop up numerous times on my OpenTable search I decided that we should give it a try. Booked a 745pm reservation on a Saturday and when we went there.. It was surprising that the restaurant was so quiet, almost near empty. A larger party was in the back area and the bar housed only a few individuals. The food was great. Bf had the burger, friend opted out of the non-pasta dish and went with the cheese platter. They both really liked their option. Too bad the waitress was so unenthusiastically ho-hum. Either we offended her by being there or she just was having a bad day. Regardless our service by her was lackluster and almost offensive to say the least. Over all not food good, service bad.
author: Yennie N.

description:
If you are looking for good old fashioned comfort food this is your spot. I had the fried chicken, sweet potato mash and collard greens. Southerners come on in and be pleased. My husband had the Braised Free-Range Lamb Shank and it just fell off of the bone. This is how it's supposed to be made, but often just isn't!

But the real treat was the Abbey Road (house infused cucumber gin, basil syrup, meyer lemon, fresh basil and soda). This drink was heaven! I had two. Yummy.
author: Pamela A.

description:
Lamb shank was falling off the bone.  Fried Chicken had a authentic southern flair, and the greens were the real deal.

New Chef, this place is a gem in the rough.
author: Michael B.

description:
It's kinda wierd that this place is not noticeable. It's on one of the busiest streets daytime and nighttime. The best part is that it is not frequented by tourists. It's a two-hit combo. First, it's a really good coffee place, unique and not too trendy. The guy who works the bar usually knows what he is doing, and isn't a two-bit Starbucks guy (no offense, there are actually decent Starbucks employees out there, though oftentimes I feel few). 

The second combo is the sit-down eating. The food is great, and moderately priced. I really agree with everyone who says why this place isn't packed. I've been here for lunch, oh so good, and I can only guess that with all other things going on, it could only be better with the good food. It is a good yelp outing, and it is right across the street from where I work!
author: Michael C.

description:
My friends and I attempted to have dinner here before the Margaret Cho show, but thanks to the slo-o-o-o-o-w service we arrived late and had to stand for the entire show.  
Basically the hostess at the front took our names down then never came back to seat us.  We inquired at the bar, and the bartender said she should be back soon.  Finally we decided to eat at the bar so we could get to the show on time, but then the bartender never came back to us.  The restaurant and bar were practically empty, so I found it crazy that it took so long for the bartender to finally give us menus.  
I don't know if I'll give this place another chance, but at least the food was tasty.
author: Jen T.

description: Stopped in for lunch after the Museum, only about 25% of the tables were occupied.  The food was only average and my wife's order was wrong, this after waiting for 45 minutes for our lunch.  It is obvious that customer services in not important since they have little competition in the area unless you want a taco down the street.  This observation was also noted by others on this site.
author: Michael W.

description: By one o'clock the lunch crowd will have mostly cleared and you can secure one of those nice velvety booths with the comfy pillows for you and your dining companion. The lemonade here is a must- not overly sweet, lots of zingy lemon flavor. The veggie burger is excellent as well. A place I'd definitely return to for lunch when in the area.
author: Miriam W.

description:
I want to commend the staff for being so professional when dealing with rude customers.  I watched as a couple at a nearby table complained left and right.  They complained about portions and how reviews had said such and such and this wasn't what the review said.  At one point they asked the waiter if he had eaten the lamb at such and such a restaurant.  He said the lamb here couldn't hold a candle to it and he should try the lamb at this other restaurant.  RUDE!  At every step the waiter brought more bread, more food, and never balked at trying to improve a 'bad' experience this couple had fabricated.  So kudos to the staff for excellent service even for those who don't deserve it.

There was nothing about my dining experience that required complaining about.  The only thing I needed to emphasize to my waiter was that my experience was nothing but positive.  Although the food didn't stand out for me, it certainly didn't disappoint.  Additionally I liked the paintings, lighting fixtures and vibe of the place.
author: Parker W.

description: Got the veggie burger. It had some weird spice/aftertaste so i couldn't finish it. Fries were decent. It wasn't that busy but we still had to wait a bit to be seated. Atmosphere was nice.
author: Roxy B.

description: Both the service and the food were excellent. In and out in time for a nearby 7:30pm SF Ballet performance. The pork chop and risotto easily the most delicious I've had in a long time. Good Manhattan and Martini cocktails, too.
author: John M.

description:
I live right down the street so was hoping this would be a nice neighborhood bar/restaurant to visit frequently, however after 3 attempts I still find it lacking...

Here's why..

Went there the first time on New Years Eve for dinner and drinks.  The waiter, although friendly, seemed to be hopped/sped-up on something and unfortunately delivered our appetizer BEFORE our first drink (and this was after reminding him that we did not receive our drink).  The place was pretty busy, but not busy enough to warrant this.

(The food was mediocre, and pretty pricey for what was delivered.)

Went a second time on a Thursday night for a drink.  The bar tender clearly (Asian guy, I think) had an attitude and was not friendly in the least.  The place had only one party eating dinner and the environment was pretty much a bore.

Went a third time for drinks on a Monday night.  The owner was bar tending, and was pretty friendly, but nothing other than appetizers were served due to it being a slow Monday night.

Haven't been back since in the 3 months I've lived here...

Overall, I was pretty let down with this place.  Seems to have potential, but something is amiss.  

You'd think they'd want to be "that neighborhood place" for the Hastings law students and others in the area, but they aren't doing enough to make it feel that way.  

Mediocre food, high prices, bar tenders who think they're the isht and boring atmosphere; makes for a yawn and a search for something better.
author: Eric S.

description:
After jury duty I wandered around the area looking for lunch and found Soluna on my scoutmob app. For 50% off I thought it would be a good meal and good place to kill time. The ambiance is nice, plush red booths in the back of the restaurant and a nicer feel than it gives off on the outside. Once in, I decided to go for the salmon burger and Mac and cheese. Priced at $12/each, the portions and quality were definitely subpar. The sandwich was dry and bland, the Mac and cheese was good but a pretty small portion for the price. Since I was using the deal I wasn't too concerned with the price, but had i paid full price i would have been much more disappointed. To top it off, they included 18% gratuity for a party of 1 (apparently part of the scoutmob deal although I've never had to pre-tip when I've used it before) and then they ALSO taxed the gratuity...wait, isn't that illegal?! I'm preeetty sure it is. When I asked the server about it she just said a lot of ppl ask the same question but she doesn't know. 

At the end of the meal my bill racked up to about $20 which is more than I usually spend on a Monday afternoon, but more importantly, I just didn't enjoy my meal. As I walked out of the restaurant my lunch choice felt like a waste and I don't plan on returning here. I should've stuck with my original plan to go to Saigon Sandwiches for lunch...a viet sando would've def hit the spot.
author: Shafaq C.

description:
We chose to dine at this fine establishment after seeing Wicked at the Orpheum theatre (sooo good, by the way). I had gone to the Orpheum website to see what was nearby as I don't frequent SF enough to know the area. The website had about 12 suggestions and each restaurant offered "come to our restaurant and we'll give you a free a) drink b) appetizer 3) dessert when you show us your ticket stub". UM AWESOME. So, we did. I looked at all 12 and ended up choosing Soluna. I am sooo glad I did for the following reasons: 

1) Did I say it's only 2 blocks from the theatre? No more "re-parking" and paying another $20 to park at another garage. 

2) Wine list is to die for 

3) The waitress took our coats and hung them in the back so they didn't get wrinkled. 

4) The menu is small which is awesome so you don't have to think too hard about what you want to eat. 

5) Ordered the crab stuffed Sole. My mouth waters just thinking about it. 

6) Ambiance is amazing - awesome decor. 

7) My water glass was never empty. The water-dispenser person (not our waitress) almost was annoying she came around so much. 

8) 2 blocks from the theatre - did I already say that? 

My only complaint was that our waitress rarely came around. In fact, my mom ordered decaf coffee after our meal (I was on glass 3 of wine) and although she had a half cup left, she asked for more when the waitress finally did show. I said, "Why'd you ask for more? You have some?" My mom's response, "It's the principal that she never asked me for more." HA. Okay, so the waitress' service was to be desired, but I can't give less stars because everything else was so perfect. It was an amazing ending to a perfect day.

Oh, and they have happy four Monday - Friday.  :)
author: Kristin D.

description:
The food here is not innovative but well done.  I had the southern fried chicken which was really flavorful and tasty.  Usually, I think everything would taste better with hot sauce but the batter must've been very well spiced because I didn't think it was necessary.  

The decor is nice although the bathroom could use renovating.  
Depending on the bartender, the drinks can be fantastic.  

It's never crowded so it's a good place to go if you need a last minute place for dinner.
author: Seong P.

description:
This is a great place to have dinner before you go to a show in the Civic Center area.  The service was top notch.  The bartender, Zoe is also a sweetheart.  Love her!  

Overall the food was great, the wine list was decent, and the staff was super attentitive.  Would definitely go back!
author: DJ P.

description:
I thought the menu was amazing. The crab bisque was great and a very large portion, the heirloom salad was fresh and wonderful, and the bartender's original beverages were perhaps the highlight of the restaurant. I don't normally enjoy gin, but his recipe of a gin-based beverage called "Mr. Pink" was absolutely wonderful, he was right in saying you couldn't "taste" the gin. 
Sadly, the service didn't live up to the menu and flavors of the food and drinks. I don't know if someone botched their shift, or if something else was amiss or they didn't plan for the high volume of diners in the restaurant on a Friday evening (:-/) but the service was extremely slow. We never received bread, our bread plates were sadly lonely on our table. The drinks took forever to arrive (granted, one bartender for a busy restaurant) and my boyfriend was dismayed to find his "medium rare" steak arrived rare, and cold. We didn't have time to refire our food, because it took so long to arrive in the first place.
So it would have been five stars for the food, but the organization and service lost a couple stars for me on this busy Friday night.
author: Sarah H.

description:
Wow - the lunch that I had at Soluna was so tasty!  Four Stars!  But wait, I want to give them minus-3 stars.  How did that happen?

Did the host get snippy with me when I walked in and let him know that my 14 guests and I were there and had reservations?  Yep!  Minus one star.

Then many ordered Diet Coke.  When served, the soda was VERY sweet and didn't taste like Diet Coke.  I asked the waitress to confirm the soda flavor and she started arguing with me.  It finally came down to me saying, "Look, you have unhappy guests.  Please do me a favor and make sure that they have what they need to make them happy."  Yep, I had to remind her that she was responsible for customer service.  Minus a star.

Then she ROLLED her eyes at me when I turned around.  Rolled her eyes.  I brought in a table of 15 expensive lunches and the b@$ch rolled her eyes.  Minus a star.

Turns out the soda was Diet RC.  They're too cheap to buy Diet Coke and they didn't bother to educate their employees on their products.  Minus one star.

When it was time to order, she was trying to do everyone in a line, to keep the orders straight, making serving easier.  When someone didn't realize this and ordered out of line, she yelled at him.  Minus one star.

The food came out in a timely manner, for such a large group in a full restaurant.  Plus one star.

The server tried to give someone a cup of soup when he ordered a bowl.  He corrected her, that's fine.  What's not fine is that she tried to give him the same cup of soup 3 times, until someone asked her if she didn't want to give him a bowl.  Then a bowl came out.  Minus one star.

Serving was a mess.  After making a big deal about "keeping orders in order", there was no order to the chaos of serving.  Minus one star.

The waitress NEVER came back to ask if everything was OK and just plunked the check on the table.  Minus one star.

Where does that leave us, dear Yelp reader?  4-1-1-1-1-1+1-1-1-1 = -3... too bad Yelp doesn't let you rate that low.

Go to Absinthe or Citizen Cake instead!  On the way out, the host said "come back soon".  Yeah... right.  And I'm as dumb as a brick.
author: Leigh S.

description:
We arrived shortly after 5pm when they opened for dinner. We didn't have a reservation so they offered my partner and I a seat at on of the tables in the bar area. Those tables have those high bar stools. My partner sat down and mentioned that this would be quite uncomfortable for a whole meal (she's about 5' tall and I'm a couple inches shorter so our feet dangle a great deal). The host overheard me suggest that we go somewhere else and quickly offered us a regular table with the condition that we complete our meal by 6:30pm for a reservation they were expecting. This wasn't a problem to us but the entire place was empty so I wasn't sure why it was necessary. 

I told the waiter that I wanted the prixe fix menu (one starter, one entree, one dessert) and that made him anxious due to the time constraint. Again, the place was empty, so why wouldn't they have time for this? We understood the time issue and we weren't intending to dilly dally or to give the wait staff a hard time. They seated a table of 4 right next to us who also didn't have a reservation. Our waiter was extra nice to them -- a table of 4 older people (one with a loud Hawaiin-style shirt with the Golden Gate Bridge all over it), emphasizing that they can take their time and even chatting it up with them. He showed a completely different personality with them. He treated us like we were a burden. 

As for the food, I liked 2 of the 3 tunas (served 3 ways: ceviche, poke and, my least favorite, peppercorn crusted). The peppercorn crusted was served with bland haricot verts and the ahi tuna was lacking flavor and overrun with pepper.The lamb was awesome and the risotto and veggies were pretty good. The bacon wrapped halibut was good but still felt like it was missing something. My partner really liked the baby spinach and pear salad. 

Our time was now 6pm (a half hour before our promised time to exit) so I decided to take my dessert to go. I was full, anyway. The waiter gave us dessert menus and emphasized "to go, right?" several times, like he was rushing us out. There were still several open tables at this time. I got the strawberry shortcake (delicious vanilla gelato and strawberries, topped with a cookie so bland that I threw it out). It took them a while to get us the bill and now at 6:30pm, there were still open tables. I was looking for the couple with the reservation that were to take over our table and there weren't any. They didn't have reason to rush us at all. 

We felt judged and mistreated, concluded that it was because we looked ordinary and didn't display any reason for them to kiss our ass. Overall I was uncomfortable and most of the food was lacking and overpriced. It was a depressing first impression. Our server gave us a fake sounding speech about how he hoped we enjoyed ourselves.

I might come back to try something off their lunch menu but I doubt I'll have reason to do it. Maybe they're better for cocktails and night events.
author: Elsie M.

description:
This is one of the few business-style restaurants in the area and the food is pretty good all round. The Mac and Cheese is a favourite and the calamari is pretty good too.

It's let down slightly by a poor draught beer selection, with only three to choose from, but it's primarily a restaurant so that's understandable.

Movie nights on mondays are worth a visit - $3 beers, a bar menu and a large screen make for quite an enjoyable evening.
author: Iain T.

description:
I have been here twice.  The first time was after my friend's wedding and we only had drinks.  It was just us and the bartender and the experience was fine.  

The second time was with coworkers.  The waitress was slow, rude and appeared highly annoyed that we were there.  She was also sloppy and poured water all over me and a coworker while trying to fill our water glasses.  It felt weirdly intentional.  The food was really good, but the service was too terrible for me to want to go back.
author: Sofia M.

description:
The crab bisque was GREAT and the cheese platter was also very good. Our entrees on the other hand... perhaps we ordered the wrong items (lamb with flavorless risotto and chicken) , but we weren't impressed. 

The service, and this is where the one star comes from... was pathetic. But to their credit, it was very busy and I can see how that would be stressful. However it takes no time at all to smile and pretend to enjoy your job- and then of course do it well, which was also not achieved. 

As for location and proximity to the Orpheum theater and Civic Center Bart station, it was perfect.
author: Maria F.

description: They sat us near the back, and there were fruit flies EVERYWHERE.  We spent the lunch swatting them away from our admittedly tasty food.  The quality of the food would have assuaged this rating, but for the dead fly in my water glass, which I did not notice until the end of the meal.
author: Charles Y.

description:
Tasty! The salmon was cooked flawlessly and clearly quite fresh, the pork was a bit dry but remarkably tender, and the sweet potato/bacon hash (as reported elsewhere) was beyond glorious. Wines average $35/bottle and there's a reasonable one-page list. Appetizers were a bit more variable in quality - the duo of crab was unremarkable at best, while the mushroom risotto was pretty good.
Read my full review here: http://sibilous.blogspot.com/2006/07/soluna-cafe.html
author: Don H.

description:
Soluna used to be one of my go-to places for lunch. But they changed their menu a while back and all of a sudden everything seemed more expensive and with smaller portions. 

What they do, they do well, in terms of taste and stuff. But, at least for lunch, it seems to be less and less worth it.
author: Andie J.

description: A lovely place to drop in for a brief drink, but the kitchen needs some work. We arrived and had to chase down the host, who was kibbutzing in the rear of the restaurant. As we perused the menu and asked our wait staff a few questions, quite literally the first three drinks and the two appetizers that appeared on the menu were no longer available. So, why not remove them? Then when we asked about portions, we were told that the fried chicken entree consisted of five to six pieces along with vegetables and biscuit. Well, we decided to share since that seemed like a lot of food. It turned out that there was a drumstick, thigh, and breast. Okay not a problem since they were rather good sized pieces. But the carrots were beyond al dente. We need to ask for steak knives to cut the crudités they were so hard. Finally the entire plate of food was cold, not room temp, not just slightly warm, but stone cold. Next time? We will walk the distance to the Boxing Room for great service and great warm food. Why the two stars? Our server was friendly, if inept.
author: La Gata M.

description: We should have known that during lunch hour there were only 2 tables occupied... but the menu looked decent.  I asked the waitress about the temperature of the roast turkey sandwich and she said the meat was "room temperature"... I explained that I am pregnant and food has to be served hot for food poisioning concerns, then through lots of round and round she said yes it was cooked in the oven at the time of serving (earlier she said the turkey is roasted in the morning then sits out throughout the day and is sliced at serving time, which seems against food code).  Well I get the sandwich (which was over half dark meat on the sandwich, maybe that is to be expected but it shocked me) and she was correct, the meat was ROOM TEMPERATURE.  So I flagged someone else down (our waitress never once returned to our table) and asked that they heat up the sandwich and explained I do need the meat hot.  That took over 10 minutes.  When I got the sandwich at a temperature I could actually eat there was no extra flavor, just plain turkey and bland cheese.  They must have forgot the dijon sauce, or just put so little on it didn't have flavor.  I was so hungry I ate half and put the other half aside, when the manager asked how it was I explained I have to take it home to add flavor to it and I had flagged down another waiter to get a cup of soup.  Well over 10 minutes later 2 cups of soup come... the manager offered to box up my sandwich and said the $3.50 soup was complimentary, which I guess was a better option to them than the $12 sandwich that I didn't like, but I could tell they wouldn't take it off the bill so I might as well get a few dollars worth of the sandwich with some Hidden Valley Ranch dressing.... or ANYTHING really.  Then the bill comes, they had double charged the soup... after 7 minutes they came to pick up the credit cards and I explained so they took the second soup off the bill.  I will say the carrot ginger soup was quite good.  But it wasn't worth the $16.00 bill and hour and 15 minutes.  Poor customer service (the waitress said she would check to see if the temperature was ok when I ordered, she never did...) and food was very subpar.
author: Amanda Y.

description:
Hayes Valley is a great place to have a meal right before a show or anytime at all really if you're in the area. My parents have tickets for the ballet and symphony, so when they are in the area I get a free meal :) This place is one of my favorites because it made great leftovers! It was a very hearty meal which is not something you see very often at a restaurant like this or in an area like this. The flavors were very full and from what I can remember the wine list was pretty good.

I think this place deserves 3.5 stars because the dessert was not impressive. We ordered the Creme Brulee (one of my fav desserts of all time) and the Pot de Creme. Both were extremely heavy and were more like fudge.  The meal is definitely hearty enough to be able to leave without ordering dessert and that is what I would recommend.
author: Jen S.

description:
I've been coming here for quite a few years for happy hours since my office is practically a few feet away. I've always been impressed with the happy hours: good drinks at a good price (and now new, beautiful wine glasses), decent nosh, and friendly service. For a meal, though, there's a different story to tell.

My boyfriend and I went here for dinner before seeing Wicked. They were understandably reserved for the night, but were kind enough to squeeze us in with the understanding that we'd be done within an hour when that reservation was due to come. We probably would have been if it hadn't taken 10 minutes just to take our order. Again, there is absolutely nothing to complain about the service here, though; everyone was very nice. The food, though....

I ordered the lamb shank. Although the lamb was done well (not well done, mind  you) and fell off the bone, it and the accompanying veggies and risotto were sitting in a pool of some combination of butter and oil. I was able to eat the top of the risotto, but the veggies weren't edible at all with all that butter. 

Bottom line: great happy hour spot, but go somewhere else for dinner.
author: Amy B.

description:
Soluna's Happy Hour starts at 2.30.  That gets you four stars.  Period.  Yes, some people do start happy hour at 2.30 these days.  $2 off all wine, cheaper beer, and usually like one speciality cocktail at a discount.  

The food is fine, totally solid if you happen to find yourself at one of the courts nearby or the asian art musuem.  Not really a need to go out of your way to eat there but solid choice if nearby, esp at 2.30.  Did I say that already?
author: Stephanie M.

description:
FAIL, for the second time. Dinner was a huge disappointment. Service was slow; it took the waitress 30 minutes after we were seated to take our order and ten minutes after that to bring bread to the table. I ordered a salad that included seared tuna, which I asked to have cooked; when the salad finally showed up, 75 minutes after we were originally seated at our table, the tuna was too rare to eat. Sending it back the the kitchen was not an option as we had theater tickets, so I had a plate of greens for dinner. They comped the salad, but should have comped the entire meal since it left us in a foul mood. 
We had previously had trouble with service and gave our dessert to the diners at the next table because it came too late for us to eat it. That incident was blamed on new kitchen staff. 
Enough of this place...once shy, twice burned...no chance for a redux
author: J. F.

description: Really pretty place - relaxing atmosphere. Even when it was full, you could still carry on a conversation without yelling. Food is all organic, local and sustainable. Fantastic & friendly service. Fun cocktail menu. The green salad and salmon were wonderful! Don't miss the red potato smash. Make sure to make a reservation - it filled up. Only negative was the bread pudding we had for dessert. Not moist enough - way too dry. Otherwise a great place to eat near Civic Center.
author: Ira B.

description: Tried this again and had a much better experience this time around. Sat at the bar for a while, the bartender was great -- conjured up an interesting, non-alcoholic beverage for my friend. Menu still interesting and food was very good -- fries with the aioli excellent. Friendly and hospitable service, albeit a trifle slow at the end (post-entree/coffee stage.) Just be sure to mention if you have performance tickets or are in a rush.
author: Rob E.

description: Did not like the fries, steak was way too fatty. Good service though, mac and cheese was reasonable, drinks was good too, over all, not memorable.
author: Tiff W.

description:
:( I soooo did not enjoy my experience here.

I had dinner here right before Wicked. Luckily Wicked saved the day... or else the evening would've been a bust.

First of all, the food was funky. I had mac and cheese and I forget what my friend had, some meat dish... it looked unappetizing.

The pasta from the mac and cheese was not thoroughly cooked, either that or it was burned or over baked in the oven, cause it was all CRUNCHY here and there. And the cheese was not nearly sharp or tasty enough, it was a really bland cream sauce.

Second of all, we told the waiter from the moment we entered that we were going to watch a show in about 2 hours so if he could hurry it up. 2 hours, with ample warning, should be enough time to eat a 3 course meal. But he totally wiped out and forgot that we needed to get the hell out of there so we ended up boxing up our desserts to go so that we could make it to the show on time.

Lastly, the whole reason we went in the first place is because they were advertising some special pre-fixe dinner menu, that somehow still added up to $50 a person for seriously sucky mediocre food. And we didn't even DRINK.

I would never recommend this place. Unless you are trying to get rid of someone or break up with someone, I would not take them here.
author: ting b.

description:
My husband and I went to Soluna for dinner this evening and were very disappointed.

Initially we were seated in the middle of the restaurant in front of the DJ and behind a large group of diners who were very noisy and who kept walking around the aisle in front of our table. We asked to move to a quieter table and were moved to the other end of the restaurant. Moments later we were asked to move again to make room for a large group. Once the large group arrived the service deteriorated. I had to ask the server to top up my water three times. we had to alert the server to pick up our plates, bring the next course etc and the cheque they gave us was wrong.

The food was passable - nothing special - forgettable. The portion sizes were very large, which might be a plus for some people.

On the whole a big . . . NO!
author: Writer G.

description:
It was exactly an A-OK experience.  I would come here again but it wouldn't be on my suggestion.

I came here for lunch and had a great time with the people I was with.  I had a mojito and some type of sandwich.  However, the food was blah, service was blah, drink was ok.  

Maybe I'm just a little biased b/c it's so closed to where I live and I like places not in my area more.  Who knows?
author: F K.

description: Went for happy hour early. The waitress was outright rude to me and my friend. When she brought our drinks we responded with a polite thank you and she simply said "mhmm". Then, we were asked to move to a smaller table to which we agreed, but we told them that we were almost done and would just take the check (it took 20 minutes to come)  THEN when our bill came we were over charged for one of the glasses of wine we ordered, and incorrectly rang up. When questioned about it we were told "it's the same price any way" IT WAS NOT! Needless to say, by the end we paid the inflated bill and left.   We bought multiple drinks and food, it wasn't like we were cheapskates either, it would have been nice to see some hospitality!
author: Lauren B.

description:
I had lunch again today at Soluna, and it was much better than my first experience. It might have to do with the change in ownership (name to soon be changed to Civic), but I thought they deserved an extra star. Service was fantastic, and the food was really good. I had a delcious nicoise salad, with really fresh tuna, and a yummy, light dressing. Definitely one of the better options in you're in the Civic Center area.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Ahhh...dining in the TL. I wanted to like Soluna, I really did. It's one of the only decent lunch spots around my office building, so I had high hopes. Maybe it was just what I ordered, but I was totally disappointed. I had the Mediterranean Salad, which was really lacking in flavor. Just a few olives, iceberg lettuce (which I hate), a little feta, and some pine nuts. It was supposed to be accompanied by warm pita bread, but instead came with a couple of pieces of stale bread. My dining companion's Nicoise salad looked a hell of a lot better. Service was great though, so maybe I'll be back...I'll just be sure to order something different.
author: Brianne K.

description:
I went here for a lunch meeting, and it was pretty decent.  I had the mac and cheese and found it to be both hearty and good.  I liked the mix of cheesy goodness.  

The atmosphere is pretty laid back and it is actually a nice restaurant in the middle of the tenderloin.  Worth going back to again.
author: Joanna S.

description:
***
8/31/07
I'm a big fan of second chances.  I just went back here for lunch and had a very good grilled chicken sandwich with roasted red peppers, tasty seasoned fries and mixed greens.  The service was friendly and efficient.  I would still steer way clear of the crabcakes though if I were you.
***

The desserts are yummy and the salds and sandwiches are usually a safe bet.  This place changed owners a while back and the vibe changed a bit.  I miss the coffee and pastries they used to sell in the mornings.  At any rate, it is one of the few clean, decent lunch spots that the Civic Center has to offer so we thank them for that.
author: Christina K.

description:
My boyfriend and I went to Soluna for a Valentine's Day dinner before going to see Wicked at the Orpheum. I was kind of cautious after the mixed reviews here...but I have to say we were very happy with our experience. We had reservations for 6:30 but we got there at 6 hoping to be sat a little earlier so we wouldn't be rushing to get to the 8 o'clock show and they sat us right away. 

We had to do the Prix Fixe Menu so I ordered the Arugula salad and the New York Strip and my boyfriend ordered the Caesar salad and the New York Strip. My salad was pretty good, but the Caesar salad was VERY good. Our steaks came with "crisp potato puffs" that were unlike any form of potato I've had before and were just to die for. For dessert, I had the Creme Brulee which was amazing and my bf had the bread pudding which he enjoyed very much. 

We didn't have to wait long for our food, but the girl that was bringing out the food to the tables didn't seem to know where the food went. She gave our salads to the table next to us and almost gave our steaks to them as well. And then after we had finished our steaks she brought the entrees of the table next to us to our table. It wasn't a big deal, just a little annoyance. As for the decor, I didn't have any problems with it whatsoever.

We were out of there by 7:30 and walked to the theatre with time to spare.
author: Adrienne M.

description:
Headed to Soluna to have dinner before a concert at the Herbst Theatre.

We had reservations at 6:15 but got there at 6PM. The hostess said that we can be seated whenever we wanted and so we decided to grab a drink at the bar. First the bartender ignored us for a good 5 minutes (we were the only ones sitting at the bar). Second, he avoided eye contact at all cost for another 5 minutes while he took the orders of two ladies that came up after us. (I promise I showered and smelled rather nice if I don't say so myself).  He finally acknowledge us and said he would be right with us, didn't hand us a drink or wine menu (that would have taken him 1/2 a second to place in our hands). The "be right with you" took another few minutes to materialize. 

We finally got our glasses of wine and we're ready to move to our table, we flagged down the hostess and she brushed us off with "I'll be right with you" ....forgetting that we already had a reservation. She disappeared for a sometime before coming up to us apologizing that she  totally forgot about us. (figured)

Ah, we finally get seated and the waitress was great. The food was really delicious and that made everything else in the service department a littler more tolerable. 

Another odd thing though, it was barely 8PM and it looked they were getting ready to close up. Amidst our dessert eating they started turning out lights in the back area of the dinning room (which we were right next to), they started lowering a screen right above our table for projecting a film or some sort. We had asked them what they were doing and the waitress said they rarely use the tables in the back after 8PM and they often show films on the lowered screen - which is fine but it was kinda odd to do all of this right above us and around us as were eating. They literally could have waited 5 minutes and we would have been out of there. 

Anyways, go there for the food. Don't expect much in the way of real service except for your waitress maybe but, I think we got lucky and had like the best-est one in the house.
author: Kristina A.

description:
Trying to find a nice place to eat lunch around 9th street is hard.  And I mean nice, not just finding something that is palatable.  And Soluna is just that, nice.  Nice decor, good food, good service.  Nothing particularly spectacular but if you just need to treat yourself or if you are going to lunch with colleagues or a working lunch and you work in the ghetto, well then, this is a place I say yes to.  

However I have to say I'm super picky because I've only had the grilled cheese sandwich.  Which was good but just looking at the menu I think that is the only thing I'm going to like.  But hell if you want a grilled cheese sandwich....
author: Alexis B.

description: The burger with blue cheese was awesome and the fries were great too.  the bread pudding was great too. Only problem was our group of 8 had to wait almost half an hour to get our first drink.  Very pleasant staff.  Make sure you have plenty of time to spend!
author: Jeff M.

description:
Went here for the second time before attending a show.  As we had been there before and didn't remember anything unpleasant we thought we'd go again.
First off we had no reservations so we had to sit at the bar section as there was a party coming in soon.  The service was mediocre up to the point the party started to arrive.  Then it became almost inexistent.  Although the staff was friendly when we saw them they were never there.  Guess they were following the tips from the big party.
We ordered from a very limited menu.  I had the fried chicken and my date the pork loin.  The loin was ok and really no complaints.  However the chicken was served in four pieces.  A leg, thigh, wing, and what looked like a chicken strip (or tender).  All the chicken was very undercooked with red around the bones.  That is all except the strip.  That was ok, however, like I said it was skinless (like a chicken tender) and had a completely different taste to the batter.  Since it tasted like a buffalo wing I suspect it came from the bar appetizer menu.  How it made it to my plate I will never know.  In addition to the chicken the menu stated I was to get a biscuit.  Looked high and low, no biscuit.
I was going to give the place two stars and one last thing came to mind.  Fruit flies were everywhere.  We were constantly waving them away from our faces and our plates.  That tells me something somewhere is not being attended to.  Maybe I should post this to the Board of Health.
All and all, the location is good if you need something close before attending the theater but you may want to explore a short cab ride to a better place.
author: Tod S.

description:
Had my doubts about this place, but was pretty hungry for some late afternoon lunch so popped in. They seem to have a real liking for the rosemary here. I ordered the pulled pork, which was drier than most places, but not in a bad way, very tasty! I ordered sans onions and on anything but an onion hoagie, I especially have doubts they have decent hoagie bread - since that comes from Philly, yo. They tossed it on a rosemary ciabatta for me. The sammies come with salad and fries, which are speckled with rosemary and garlic and crisped to perfection. Also enjoyed the rosemary corn chowder, unawares of all the rosemary to come with my entree. Rounded the afternoon out with a $7 glass of ok Pinot Noir, Five Rivers I believe it was. 
The staff seemed like a bunch of CCA flunkies, but they were ok enough. I maybe would visit Soluna again, in a pinch.
author: Colleen B.

description:
Lunch: most of the sandwiches are excellent. The entrees are too small for the price.   Great ambience and for a nice long chat.

Dinner: haven't tried yet.

Other perks: Lots of local politicians go there for lunch. Gavin has been spotted here several times.
author: Bessie T.

description:
Soluna is a quaint cafe & lounge located just around the corner from The Asian Art Museum. It's also a nice change from your average Tenderloin eateries. I've only been here for lunch, I wuold like to stop by sometime for happy hour.

I had a lovely lunch which was moderately priced. My salad was delicious and definitely hit the spot. Service was good, relaxed, not rushed. 

Yes, I would gladly go back to Soluna sometime although it's fairly unlikely since I don't work in the neighborhood anymore.
author: alexa c.

description:
What a wonderful location! Nice view of SF City Hall. Just around the corner from a BART station. And a short walk from the opera. 

I recently attended a private event here. The food was good, the service was outstanding. What a great crew! I found the drinks... um, small and not really noteworthy. Probably 'cause I was too distracted by the pleasant surroundings, the large screen and good sound system. Would definitely be excited to have another event here.

I'll come back for sure to have dinner before attending the opera.
author: Wella L.

description:
I had the ahi tuna sandwich w/ salad and fries.  The fries were tasty and came seasoned with garlic salt.  The salad was average and tasted like it had a very light dressing.  The sandwich was disappointing, and the portion was tiny.  The piece of tuna was tiny as well.  Overall,  disappointing and very pricey (for what you get and what Soluna is).  

Someone recommended the burger, so I might try it but hope to avoid this place.
author: David L.

description:
3 stars for the beautiful decor, the friendly waiter and location. 

Let's get into the meat of this review: The wine selection was scant and so was the food selection.

I don't understand what the rave about the parmesean truffle garlic fries was...I've had better garlic parmesean fries at baseball games for godsake. 

I ordered the Petaluma pan seared chicken with with potato fingerlings and spinich. My friend had the  salmon.

First, I have to say for a restaurant that obviously put a lot of effort and consideration into their decor, the presentation of my dish was downright awful. My whole entire entree was served in a pool of sauce. My entire meal was literally swimming in sauce. The potato fingerlings were soggy, the spinich was mush...The chicken was tough and dry. 

My friend enjoyed her salmon but wasn't impressed with the accompanying sides.

I wouldn't go out of my way to come back here again.
author: Susie O.

description: I must say that this place could easily be 4.5 to 5 stars if they could improve their service. The food is very good. Our party had the butternut squash risotto, the Arctic char, the fried chicken and the rib eye steak. Everyone loved their main course! Unfortunately it went downhill from there. One in our party wanted dessert but actually had to get up to go find someone to bring us dessert menus. We ordered one dessert, two coffees and one tea. The dessert (two scoops of interesting apple ice cream) took 15 minutes, the coffees arrived after the dessert was gone and the tea arrived 5 minutes after that. The waitress sort of apologized and said that we wouldn't be charged for the coffees but they were on the final bill. We asked her to remove them, which she did, but in splitting the bill among three credit cards, she charged $65 to one, $130 to another and $195 to the third, not exactly even. When we asked for a correction, that took another 5 minutes. It was harder to take given that a 20% gratuity was automatically entered for our party of six.  To be fair, our waitress seemed to have a large number of tables, so perhaps hiring another staff person is in order for theater nights. This is still the best option near the Orpheum, but wish they had some competition so they would step up their game a bit
author: Lyn K.

description: Surprisingly good. Came for pre-ballet dinner. Had clams and muscles in a really great broth. Mac & cheese that was above average. Tatsoi salad very good and the NY strip steak with duck fat potatoes, creamed spinach which had a little chopped walnut in it. Server Chris recommended a very nice Chardonnay (Cru). Service was first rate. Will go back.
author: Robert M P.

description: Planned a reception here on a Thur 3-6pm for about 25 people and it came off without a hitch.  Talked with Dave Bullers by phone and email and he made it all easy.  The food was great, especially the pork skewers.  The service was fantastic.  I can't wait to go back and try the pork entree for dinner.
author: Rick R.

description: Thinking of dinner at Soluna? Best go to the website and listen to what plays over the menu first, because that's the loud beat that will overpower your conversation. "That's how we do it," explained our host. Saturday night and the place was empty. No wonder. On the plus side, might be a good experience for the hearing impaired and the community garden next door is lovely
author: Stephen S.

description:
